ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar
I worked in-person in the lab, and we presented our research at the end of the semester through Zoom.
Research course - could be remote or in the wet laboratory as per COVID guidelines
in-person lab, virtual lab
Research in lab sourced by student.
Senior research project conducted primarily in the lab, with some remote reading and writing involved.
This course is for students pursuing in-person laboratory research for a senior thesis project.
Virtual presentations / peer evaluations of research presentations.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Independent laboratory and scientific skills
I was able to dedicate much more time in the lab and work on my experiments that I was doing before the pandemic shut down the lab.

I was able to spend more time on my research project semester, allowing me to home in on previous research skills. I also developed better abilities to analyze data and draw conclusions, as well as to design research experiments, work on a scientific talk, and write a grant proposal.
I learned from my lab techniques in doing science research. I conducted experiments, analyzed data, and learned to present science to a specific audience.
Bench lab skills, cell culture, mouse management, breeding, surgery, antibody usage, grant proposal writing, presentation, etc.
I worked on my senior research project in my own lab. I learned some writing and lots of presentation skills.

The course facilitated research for my senior thesis project. It provided practice with writing proposals and giving presentations, in addition to strengthening a wide variety of research skills through lab experience.
Further understanding into the biological sciences/research.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very well structured but allows independence

Strengths: this course allows students to be actively engaged in the lab and improves our presentation skills through the oral presentation and papers.
Weakness: the actual research course itself doesn't really seem to play any role in my lab experience until the very end when we have to present and write. But it seems a bit weird having the course professors grade us instead of our own PIs since we never had the opportunity to talk with the course professors throughout the semester to get their feedback.

Strengths are the information session by the instructors, such as how to give an oral presentation. The weaknesses are the lack of community-building activities and continuous check-in with the instructors. For example, it would be very helpful to meet with the instructors at least twice a semester as benchmark meetings to discuss how we are doing and what we need help on so that we can get continuous feedback during the semester rather than one at the end.

There wasn't very much instruction or clarity regarding each of the assignments. We had to turn in research proposals at the start of the semester, but no feedback or even project approval was turned over to us. Although there had been a workshop on how to give science talks toward the end of the semester, it was a bit scattered. That being said, the flexibility of options for types of research that we could engage with was very diverse, and I think many of appreciated this.

Strengths: independent work offering students plenty of decision making opportunities
Weaknesses: only one check-in during the semester to discuss presentation tips for end of semester Powerpoints

Strengths were clear guidelines and the fact that it gave you the opportunity to get more mentorship and a clear defined research project. I wish the course instructors would check in on us at least once, and give more of an indication that they read our final reports. I did not get any feedback from the instructors other than from Dr, Wolenski in the Q&A after my presentation. I also did not get to see any of the feedback from my peers.

There was little guidance given to the students from the course professors, which made it difficult to navigate the assignments and projects. We also got little to no feedback on our work from these professors so the grades given felt arbitrary. I understand most of the feedback comes from our mentor and PI, but since the course professors are involved in assessing our work it would be helpful to get more feedback to justify the grades given.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was able to research in person
The Zoom oral presentations worked effectively.

The talk seminars (done over Zoom at the end of the semester) were very well put together, and I enjoyed the chance to get to listen to other people's talks as well. I do think that more transparency regarding assignments and grading could have been passed along, such as by giving feedback on each individual assignment in a timely manner.

I felt this constant pressure to be in person and gather good data and perform good experiments, which when I engaged virtually, I was penalized by the instructors of this course for not getting good data and gathering good conclusions. I think the instructors did not really recognize what we had to go through to be undergraduate researchers during the time of COVID.
Course continued with virtual check-ins which were still useful during the pandemic. Few other engagement opportunities besides end of semester presentations.
They were very lenient about COVID, even though the pandemic made it more difficult to do in person lab work.

The online presentation from this semester provided a good model for zoom-based meetings for students in this course. I would hope that 2-3 information sessions, similar to the November end-of-semester zoom session, be included throughout the semester to create more regular contact.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes absolutely
Yes, for the senior thesis.

If you love research, this is a great way to make sure you have some protected time to work on your project (so basically, if you're already spending 15+ hours in the lab per week, you might as well take 495 over 485). But, if you don't like research or find yourself wanting to do just the bare minimum # of hours in lab, the 20 hours/week are going to be very painful.
Yes. The research opportunities and intensity are very useful for future PhD and MD students.
Yes, if you already spend a lot of time doing research in lab, might as well get more credit for it.

I would recommend this course to MCDB students pursuing a BS degree. I enjoying that  495 afforded me more time in the lab. I the extended lab time each week to be advantageous, as it allowed me to gain more exposure to different research projects and negotiate with unexpected challenges with my research project.
Well, it depends on if you want the B.S. Int. degree. If so... I mean, you have to! I'd recommend it if you're in lab a bunch anyway though. That's why I chose it.
